A yellow dressinggown, ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air.: 1.648434370501858
He held the bowl aloft and intoned:  —_Introibo ad altare Dei_.: 2.1562978243270496
Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely:  —Come up, Kinch!: 1.9957416570608153
Come up, you fearful jesuit!: 1.7447028887141942
Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest.: 1.7949924978730813
He faced about and blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the awaking mountains.: 1.5458055749426742
Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak.: 2.056095794285142
Buck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the bowl smartly.: 1.836371706168535
—Back to barracks!: 3.9736324210967684
he said sternly.: 1.2452015768802498
He added in a preacher’s tone:  —For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul and blood and ouns.: 1.7140435596838923
Slow music, please.: 1.575286407710646
Shut your eyes, gents.: 2.126773309998064
One moment.: 2.527405808955069
A little trouble about those white corpuscles.: 1.474192070869928
Silence, all.: 1.8187990221353114
He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there with gold points.: 1.5989206044980393
Chrysostomos.: 2.420709619727489
Two strong shrill whistles answered through the calm.: 2.170507950277988
—Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly.: 2.618333394803352
That will do nicely.: 2.5217587069510787
Switch off the current, will you?: 1.5896581857756003
He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering about his legs the loose folds of his gown.: 1.5542147454951776
The plump shadowed face and sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages.: 1.5267502109823299
A pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips.: 1.8149976059940165
—The mockery of it!: 1.5199001728052777
he said gaily.: 1.2388563504292613
Your absurd name, an ancient Greek!: 1.546942207480249
He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet, laughing to himself.: 1.9207419386069402
Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and lathered cheeks and neck.: 1.7113425610754645
Buck Mulligan’s gay voice went on.: 3.0506747157430802
—My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls.: 2.2411202789324927
But it has a Hellenic ring, hasn’t it?: 1.7946887432593341
Tripping and sunny like the buck himself.: 1.4390700588657515
We must go to Athens.: 2.3551985639528636
Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out twenty quid?: 1.7773090438576205
He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried:  —Will he come?: 1.8077967714461556
The jejune jesuit!: 2.0204431222267316
Ceasing, he began to shave with care.: 3.0730358218367337
—Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly.: 4.468973744099287
—Yes, my love?: 12.511212835224505
—How long is Haines going to stay in this tower?: 1.7591058822669008
Buck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder.: 1.9747071779235166
—God, isn’t he dreadful?: 3.4736335942597196
he said frankly.: 1.2366554911670782
A ponderous Saxon.: 1.2321206436677568
He thinks you’re not a gentleman.: 2.451264857975309
Bursting with money and indigestion.: 1.984726743750644
Because he comes from Oxford.: 1.8433850773715335
You know, Dedalus, you have the real Oxford manner.: 2.740442253949786
He can’t make you out.: 3.56386137529885
O, my name for you is the best: Kinch, the knife-blade.: 2.3000454549612326
He shaved warily over his chin.: 2.230622972344621
—He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said.: 2.2491677684242206
Where is his guncase?: 7.700496993829322
—A woful lunatic!: 1.3300134058407465
Mulligan said.: 1.7129012515084658
Were you in a funk?: 7.036860788033597
—I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear.: 3.44445653090083
Out here in the dark with a man I don’t know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a black panther.: 2.2137413752263426
You saved men from drowning.: 1.5865743818979985
I’m not a hero, however.: 3.5332595394666457
If he stays on here I am off.: 1.6069702563209143
Buck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade.: 1.7948064399840156
He hopped down from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily.: 2.31156950286478
—Scutter!: 5.540182956634215
he cried thickly.: 1.2165072715588032
He came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen’s upper pocket, said:  —Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor.: 1.9397576764033937
Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a dirty crumpled handkerchief.: 1.7122708771572814
Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly.: 1.4579722372727397
Then, gazing over the handkerchief, he said:  —The bard’s noserag!: 2.7487526151306843
A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen.: 1.4921455613417094
You can almost taste it, can’t you?: 2.819020732032003
He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair oakpale hair stirring slightly.: 1.9682180675499619
—God!: 13.130258689089832
he said quietly.: 2.7791313796760044
Isn’t the sea what Algy calls it: a great sweet mother?: 2.3097081086910407
The snotgreen sea.: 1.2302513351681297
The scrotumtightening sea.: 1.2302513351681297
_Epi oinopa ponton_.: 1.1719544252990588
Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks!: 2.165190403505086
I must teach you.: 1.3565530372300592
You must read them in the original.: 2.2948027086692564
_Thalatta!: 8.936658005791672
Thalatta!_ She is our great sweet mother.: 3.415662511193476
Come and look.: 1.6842139399951848
Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet.: 2.760110354345053
Leaning on it he looked down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of Kingstown.: 3.5005400650358274
—Our mighty mother!: 1.9877588207490693
Buck Mulligan said.: 1.5481045530981867
He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen’s face.: 2.310435479332205
—The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said.: 1.7496750978541225
That’s why she won’t let me have anything to do with you.: 3.359927727571067
—Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily.: 4.602519680129443
—You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother asked you, Buck Mulligan said.: 1.9537775016243857
But to think of your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and pray for her.: 1.9881277851508012
And you refused.: 1.1440223003503829
There is something sinister in you....: 1.4343104087933483
He broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek.: 1.4717916086403136
A tolerant smile curled his lips.: 2.4614590827099634
—But a lovely mummer!: 2.8656967593836393
he murmured to himself.: 1.4813627791654302
Kinch, the loveliest mummer of them all!: 3.941918179935102
He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously.: 1.615516136103808
Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve.: 2.0971978551278725
Pain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart.: 2.1105684492062027
Silently, in a dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of wetted ashes.: 1.6386112934428005
Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him.: 3.1001593119594935
The ring of bay and skyline held a dull green mass of liquid.: 1.538035130784897
A bowl of white china had stood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had torn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting.: 1.583770940109554
Buck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade.: 2.2341899887934162
—Ah, poor dogsbody!: 2.8751521283365573
I must give you a shirt and a few noserags.: 2.4145988068509356
How are the secondhand breeks?: 5.416408232590197
—They fit well enough, Stephen answered.: 1.8252472421478272
Buck Mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip.: 3.1354075296536217
—The mockery of it, he said contentedly.: 3.348803804810093
Secondleg they should be.: 1.651683951135004
God knows what poxy bowsy left them off.: 2.386235099545673
I have a lovely pair with a hair stripe, grey.: 2.3634781459668672
You’ll look spiffing in them.: 2.758481132551605
I’m not joking, Kinch.: 3.0804753824222812
You look damn well when you’re dressed.: 3.5466786768493774
—Thanks, Stephen said.: 3.609696849353742
I can’t wear them if they are grey.: 3.581510679784738
—He can’t wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror.: 3.1378329053485725
Etiquette is etiquette.: 1.18937813744319
He kills his mother but he can’t wear grey trousers.: 2.117582009322004
He folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the smooth skin.: 1.3919466263869253

Hair on end.: 1.5574528011997988
As he and others see me.: 1.837900947771392

This dogsbody to rid of vermin.: 1.2959190524984685
It asks me too.: 3.491345517680639

It does her all right.: 1.4468631850481706
The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi.: 1.2631379804884797
Lead him not into temptation.: 1.5434873175504638
And her name is Ursula.: 1.537956480370938

If Wilde were only alive to see you!: 1.8624832126419746

The cracked lookingglass of a servant.: 1.6135335123354884

God knows you have more spirit than any of them.: 1.6619616101706027

He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his.: 2.328100429599433

To ourselves...: 1.6653250864380837

In the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan’s gowned form moved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its yellow glow.: 1.922954008124781
Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor from the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning.: 1.821782701015987
—We’ll be choked, Buck Mulligan said.: 2.706968065444198
Haines, open that door, will you?: 1.5891138441059793
Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker.: 1.6437854692313683
A tall figure rose from the hammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open the inner doors.: 2.276708879620452
—Have you the key?: 5.906993403884381
a voice asked.: 6.837984880329115
—Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said.: 2.039437319261794
Janey Mack, I’m choked!: 3.0911872711595314
He howled, without looking up from the fire:  —Kinch!: 3.0481975826445957
—It’s in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward.: 3.7612782195032426
The key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been set ajar, welcome light and bright air entered.: 1.6657959161120586
Haines stood at the doorway, looking out.: 2.551304382622209
Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and sat down to wait.: 2.934071929262665
Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside him.: 1.9742257790820137
Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set them down heavily and sighed with relief.: 2.379051111264315
—I’m melting, he said, as the candle remarked when...: 3.5199128447390775
But, hush!: 1.207790627515692

Kinch, wake up!: 1.3706603355225622

Haines, come in.: 1.6996800205007074
The grub is ready.: 1.2438696727636505
Where’s the sugar?: 5.80706930704223
O, jay, there’s no milk.: 2.414939023730935

Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet.: 3.50927163058198
—What sort of a kip is this?: 2.1620596620905568
he said.: 3.156209769095999
I told her to come after eight.: 4.118918980365708
—We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily.: 3.0885955566721237

Buck Mulligan said.: 1.5481045530981867

Haines came in from the doorway and said quietly:  —That woman is coming up with the milk.: 2.69482568224614
—The blessings of God on you!: 1.5152185130053393
Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his chair.: 2.059048655433264
Sit down.: 6.742088081735048
Pour out the tea there.: 1.9318291984802438
The sugar is in the bag.: 2.7423210006598047
Here, I can’t go fumbling at the damned eggs.: 3.4621924465939893
He hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three plates, saying:  —_In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti._  Haines sat down to pour out the tea.: 2.548029772317083
—I’m giving you two lumps each, he said.: 2.2974295585329334
Buck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman’s wheedling voice:  —When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said.: 1.9894409848349053
And when I makes water I makes water.: 3.29651186369156
—By Jove, it is tea, Haines said.: 2.5645947054076363
Buck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling:  —_So I do, Mrs Cahill,_ says she.: 2.0132826440023734
_Begob, ma’am,_ says Mrs Cahill, _God send you don’t make them in the one pot._  He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled on his knife.: 2.6207834378117894
—That’s folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines.: 2.9043273563543357
Five lines of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of Dundrum.: 2.019621207676384
Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.: 1.9914655775562957
He turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his brows:  —Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan’s tea and water pot spoken of in the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads?: 1.98173029222732
—I doubt it, said Stephen gravely.: 2.905681845463239
—Do you now?: 7.626295105936395
Buck Mulligan said in the same tone.: 5.214104492849858
Your reasons, pray?: 8.237754244306577
—I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the Mabinogion.: 2.4379620809621567
Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann.: 3.1214694465903237
Buck Mulligan’s face smiled with delight.: 3.753858379031865
—Charming!: 4.849067398474481
he said in a finical sweet voice, showing his white teeth and blinking his eyes pleasantly.: 1.9647186880538998
Do you think she was?: 3.1862165213447455
Quite charming!: 1.658065147185408
Then, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened rasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf:  _—For old Mary Ann  She doesn’t care a damn.: 2.377326892929677
But, hising up her petticoats..._  He crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned.: 1.4941226979514914

—The milk, sir!: 6.620269852086293

—That’s a lovely morning, sir, she said.: 2.9356976441756224

—To whom?: 6.224395711701583
Mulligan said, glancing at her.: 3.34204292662164
Ah, to be sure!: 3.9198748178039664

—The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of the collector of prepuces.: 2.783194742309339
—How much, sir?: 2.9533064951474666
asked the old woman.: 5.092314522508776
—A quart, Stephen said.: 2.4781243903405454
Old shrunken paps.: 1.1719544252990588
She poured again a measureful and a tilly.: 2.9116621731412424
Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe a messenger.: 1.4561283674582532
Crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her toadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs.: 1.6903678289841972
They lowed about her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle.: 1.9504550710090012
Silk of the kine and poor old woman, names given her in old times.: 1.7532628035424478
A wandering crone, lowly form of an immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common cuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning.: 1.9131700785820853
To serve or to upbraid, whether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour.: 2.597180688786389
—It is indeed, ma’am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups.: 2.617769790488793
—Taste it, sir, she said.: 2.8600061468048215
He drank at her bidding.: 3.8627501229902577
—If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat loudly, we wouldn’t have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten guts.: 2.331333854526784
Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with dust, horsedung and consumptives’ spits.: 3.1672471933150623
—Are you a medical student, sir?: 3.0287994936711957
the old woman asked.: 12.200905761660662
—I am, ma’am, Buck Mulligan answered.: 2.9836189990052255
—Look at that now, she said.: 3.6703711860254025
Stephen listened in scornful silence.: 1.2865745897409122
She bows her old head to a voice that speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she slights.: 2.1357628465145124
To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there is of her but her woman’s unclean loins, of man’s flesh made not in God’s likeness, the serpent’s prey.: 1.8819085073025565
And to the loud voice that now bids her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes.: 2.003892522210721
—Do you understand what he says?: 4.21599342853957

—Irish, Buck Mulligan said.: 2.461516214991741

Are you from the west, sir?: 3.5387387859632375

—Bill, sir?: 1.7663850098315577
she said, halting.: 7.3956962961036705
Well, it’s seven mornings a pint at twopence is seven twos is a shilling and twopence over and these three mornings a quart at fourpence is three quarts is a shilling.: 1.7786327360039984
That’s a shilling and one and two is two and two, sir.: 2.894549994180396
Buck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly buttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his trouser pockets.: 1.8780059358388737
—Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling.: 2.648742887818128
Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the thick rich milk.: 1.4272173065528533

All I can give you I give.: 2.579230579014555

—We’ll owe twopence, he said.: 2.486880647906771

I’m stony.: 7.647450027572179
Hurry out to your school kip and bring us back some money.: 1.547497632731516

Ireland expects that every man this day will do his duty.: 2.1209556246177463

—All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey trickle over a slice of the loaf.: 1.9675937736014253
Speaking to me.: 2.486650686973668

Conscience.: 3.0324287377854287
Yet here’s a spot.: 7.937828702118582

Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and said with coarse vigour:  —You put your hoof in it now.: 2.057605980670401
What did you say that for?: 4.7019852674274905

Stephen said.: 3.459974694862643
The problem is to get money.: 1.5889602487690944

—There’s your snotrag, he said.: 4.599361807918446

Martello you call it?: 3.289657576767462

Is it some paradox?: 4.5515113432304855

We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes.: 1.3765149223818678
It’s quite simple.: 7.299075965978806
He proves by algebra that Hamlet’s grandson is Shakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own father.: 2.1289022645849194
—What?: 9.840555452504102
He himself?: 5.679208129249694

Japhet in search of a father!: 3.690054895675231
—We’re always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines.: 3.521588040613585
And it is rather long to tell.: 2.163895327134976

—I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this tower and these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore.: 1.8435756321035945
_That beetles o’er his base into the sea,_ isn’t it?: 2.0760353239225076
Buck Mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards Stephen but did not speak.: 1.7019865144707729
In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in cheap dusty mourning between their gay attires.: 1.547902460807585
Eyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent.: 1.6076461342939348
The seas’ ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail tacking by the Muglins.: 2.122655831381894
—I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused.: 2.385939394349303
The Father and the Son idea.: 2.7797176777266537
The Son striving to be atoned with the Father.: 4.720488823645553
Buck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face.: 1.412367298568852
He looked at them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety.: 2.2412075372940072
He moved a doll’s head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice:  _—I’m the queerest young fellow that ever you heard.: 2.5651164327944156
My mother’s a jew, my father’s a bird.: 4.750058229127542
With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree.: 1.5698436608826651
So here’s to disciples and Calvary._  He held up a forefinger of warning.: 4.011979665366591
_—If anyone thinks that I amn’t divine He’ll get no free drinks when I’m making the wine But have to drink water and wish it were plain That I make when the wine becomes water again._  He tugged swiftly at Stephen’s ashplant in farewell and, running forward to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted:  _—Goodbye, now, goodbye!: 1.8950458804032755
Write down all I said And tell Tom, Dick and Harry I rose from the dead.: 1.8536575855622446
What’s bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly And Olivet’s breezy...: 2.5998738712381755
Goodbye, now, goodbye!_  He capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his winglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury’s hat quivering in the fresh wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries.: 1.7442089268522436
Haines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and said:  —We oughtn’t to laugh, I suppose.: 2.285403088207359
He’s rather blasphemous.: 6.854028077064252

—There’s only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said.: 2.96597489032901

Haines helped himself and snapped the case to.: 1.6544656895986243
He put it back in his sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk towards Stephen in the shell of his hands.: 1.9459669253474958
—Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again.: 4.551389245455904

You don’t stand for that, I suppose?: 4.198373019180017
—You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible example of free thought.: 2.4536770147511033

My familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen!: 1.802898778885995

He wants that key.: 1.3616747599662826

All.: 6.052131618485058
He will ask for it.: 1.460689814508158
That was in his eyes.: 5.67530175261575
—After all, Haines began...: 2.976102644131054
Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not all unkind.: 1.970552667892986
—After all, I should think you are able to free yourself.: 2.147927414814702
You are your own master, it seems to me.: 1.964868061816687
—I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an Italian.: 3.046334832096263
—Italian?: 5.1080838033499205
Haines said.: 4.106572195552516
A crazy queen, old and jealous.: 1.5220249451855534
Kneel down before me.: 4.730680731327945
—Italian?: 5.1080838033499205
Haines said again.: 1.4954517937836023
What do you mean?: 8.489771634808433
—The imperial British state, Stephen answered, his colour rising, and the holy Roman catholic and apostolic church.: 1.9620712857364746
Haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he spoke.: 1.4578565694324195
An Irishman must think like that, I daresay.: 2.3465091166164456
We feel in England that we have treated you rather unfairly.: 1.6683284064700592
It seems history is to blame.: 1.3619743657155166
The proud potent titles clanged over Stephen’s memory the triumph of their brazen bells: _et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam:_ the slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own rare thoughts, a chemistry of stars.: 2.101127783756452
Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed and menaced her heresiarchs.: 1.8471343701782403
A horde of heresies fleeing with mitres awry: Photius and the brood of mockers of whom Mulligan was one, and Arius, warring his life long upon the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, and Valentine, spurning Christ’s terrene body, and the subtle African heresiarch Sabellius who held that the Father was Himself His own Son.: 1.7723190612256372
Words Mulligan had spoken a moment since in mockery to the stranger.: 1.6417820454103687
Idle mockery.: 1.5776425891193573
The void awaits surely all them that weave the wind: a menace, a disarming and a worsting from those embattled angels of the church, Michael’s host, who defend her ever in the hour of conflict with their lances and their shields.: 2.260632882405926
Prolonged applause.: 1.4478852574705654
_Zut!: 8.936658005791672
Nom de Dieu!_  —Of course I’m a Britisher, Haines’s voice said, and I feel as one.: 2.798785605159103
I don’t want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either.: 2.4003173168107566

—It was the speech, mark you, the professor said, of a finished orator, full of courteous haughtiness and pouring in chastened diction I will not say the vials of his wrath but pouring the proud man’s contumely upon the new movement.: 2.6116273018791745

IMPROMPTU   In ferial tone he addressed J.: 1.4556530118843447
O’Molloy:  —Taylor had come there, you must know, from a sickbed.: 2.379684558444199
That he had prepared his speech I do not believe for there was not even one shorthandwriter in the hall.: 2.7102714237538508

O’Molloy’s towards Stephen’s face and then bent at once to the ground, seeking.: 2.6868792393236927

He raised his head firmly.: 2.115401396576486
His eyes bethought themselves once more.: 2.0688100294975427
Witless shellfish swam in the gross lenses to and fro, seeking outlet.: 3.185062235777647
He began:  _—Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: Great was my admiration in listening to the remarks addressed to the youth of Ireland a moment since by my learned friend.: 1.749673997895816
It seemed to me that I had been transported into a country far away from this country, into an age remote from this age, that I stood in ancient Egypt and that I was listening to the speech of some highpriest of that land addressed to the youthful Moses._  His listeners held their cigarettes poised to hear, their smokes ascending in frail stalks that flowered with his speech.: 1.7844908740835457
_And let our crooked smokes._ Noble words coming.: 1.4202952351082574
Look out.: 2.9458034030546876
Could you try your hand at it yourself?: 1.6150993459237148
_—And it seemed to me that I heard the voice of that Egyptian highpriest raised in a tone of like haughtiness and like pride.: 1.9350881124255617
I heard his words and their meaning was revealed to me._  FROM THE FATHERS   It was revealed to me that those things are good which yet are corrupted which neither if they were supremely good nor unless they were good could be corrupted.: 1.7768306434446064
Ah, curse you!: 1.386841215230988
That’s saint Augustine.: 4.885540985220398
_—Why will you jews not accept our culture, our religion and our language?: 1.4139720765194055
You are a tribe of nomad herdsmen: we are a mighty people.: 3.615471689783321
You have no cities nor no wealth: our cities are hives of humanity and our galleys, trireme and quadrireme, laden with all manner merchandise furrow the waters of the known globe.: 2.0887582626865235
You have but emerged from primitive conditions: we have a literature, a priesthood, an agelong history and a polity._  Nile.: 2.2381816145876363
Child, man, effigy.: 2.567996497142549
By the Nilebank the babemaries kneel, cradle of bulrushes: a man supple in combat: stonehorned, stonebearded, heart of stone.: 2.255669364537411
_—You pray to a local and obscure idol: our temples, majestic and mysterious, are the abodes of Isis and Osiris, of Horus and Ammon Ra.: 2.2300748530781185
Yours serfdom, awe and humbleness: ours thunder and the seas.: 2.084820296699633
Israel is weak and few are her children: Egypt is an host and terrible are her arms.: 1.4535537766498376
Vagrants and daylabourers are you called: the world trembles at our name._  A dumb belch of hunger cleft his speech.: 1.8601797048659123
He lifted his voice above it boldly:  _—But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will and bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed the pillar of the cloud by day.: 1.8677138863317178
He would never have spoken with the Eternal amid lightnings on Sinai’s mountaintop nor ever have come down with the light of inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in his arms the tables of the law, graven in the language of the outlaw._  He ceased and looked at them, enjoying a silence.: 2.183225388274164

A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the castoff mail of a court buck, a wellset man with a bass voice.: 2.3557725497468787
It is the ghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who has studied _Hamlet_ all the years of his life which were not vanity in order to play the part of the spectre.: 2.1241769508382977
He speaks the words to Burbage, the young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth, calling him by a name:       Hamlet, I am thy father’s spirit,  bidding him list.: 1.9822635178248633
To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince, young Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has died in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever.: 2.0552140591497263
Is it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in the vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words to his own son’s name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been prince Hamlet’s twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that he did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you are the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the guilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?: 1.9623745954354772

The poisoning and the beast with two backs that urged it King Hamlet’s ghost could not know of were he not endowed with knowledge by his creator.: 1.9223116039075696

—Saint Thomas, Stephen smiling said, whose gorbellied works I enjoy reading in the original, writing of incest from a standpoint different from that of the new Viennese school Mr Magee spoke of, likens it in his wise and curious way to an avarice of the emotions.: 1.9770943010251265
He means that the love so given to one near in blood is covetously withheld from some stranger who, it may be, hungers for it.: 1.845683865102267
Jews, whom christians tax with avarice, are of all races the most given to intermarriage.: 1.4935620350733012

—She lies laid out in stark stiffness in that secondbest bed, the mobled queen, even though you prove that a bed in those days was as rare as a motorcar is now and that its carvings were the wonder of seven parishes.: 1.8763365147205855

She passed out with her basket and a marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and basket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed the end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had always to be told twice _bless you, my child,_ that they have been absolved, _pray for me._ But they had so many worries in life, so many cares, poor creatures.: 2.27448106240475

A stout lady stopped, took a copper coin from her purse and dropped it into the cap held out to her.: 1.7095955616695702

He halted and growled angrily:  —_For England_...: 1.5796716861701734

I’m just waiting for Ben Dollard.: 2.723801552930895
He’s going to say a word to long John to get him to take those two men off.: 2.6731510834642576
All I want is a little time.: 1.9714939263800795
He looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck.: 2.2068439149229424
—I know, Mr Dedalus said, nodding.: 4.200271072489752
Poor old bockedy Ben!: 2.146053340834639
He’s always doing a good turn for someone.: 2.7492379693471425
Hold hard!: 4.853377656384428
He put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant.: 2.5320268124785077
—There he is, by God, he said, arse and pockets.: 3.0685875063689863
Ben Dollard’s loose blue cutaway and square hat above large slops crossed the quay in full gait from the metal bridge.: 1.6727273305037265
He came towards them at an amble, scratching actively behind his coattails.: 2.0168139924174455
As he came near Mr Dedalus greeted:  —Hold that fellow with the bad trousers.: 2.2103890785141207
—Hold him now, Ben Dollard said.: 2.243719411826291
Mr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben Dollard’s figure.: 1.5707942585820471
Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered sneeringly:  —That’s a pretty garment, isn’t it, for a summer’s day?: 2.6278313122222214
—Why, God eternally curse your soul, Ben Dollard growled furiously, I threw out more clothes in my time than you ever saw.: 1.8116630526321345
He stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes from points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying:  —They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow.: 2.2396618938411557
—Bad luck to the jewman that made them, Ben Dollard said.: 1.8699247464193756
Thanks be to God he’s not paid yet.: 5.079165460267867
—And how is that _basso profondo_, Benjamin?: 5.332825058648035
Father Cowley asked.: 1.230150626045368
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, murmuring, glassyeyed, strode past the Kildare street club.: 2.0006471136328616
Ben Dollard frowned and, making suddenly a chanter’s mouth, gave forth a deep note.: 1.8760954979726117
—Aw!: 5.540182956634215
he said.: 3.156209769095999
—That’s the style, Mr Dedalus said, nodding to its drone.: 3.647909117600813
—What about that?: 5.01251459890783
Ben Dollard said.: 1.8206355228742361
—That’ll do, Father Cowley said, nodding also.: 3.7170295054363223
The reverend Hugh C.: 1.1502055004135254
Love walked from the old chapterhouse of saint Mary’s abbey past James and Charles Kennedy’s, rectifiers, attended by Geraldines tall and personable, towards the Tholsel beyond the ford of hurdles.: 2.5869715734009597
Ben Dollard with a heavy list towards the shopfronts led them forward, his joyful fingers in the air.: 1.685063002676578
I want to show you the new beauty Rock has for a bailiff.: 2.1152348941113908
He’s a cross between Lobengula and Lynchehaun.: 3.7477446619678116
He’s well worth seeing, mind you.: 3.304459392417579
Come along.: 6.32225493368968
I saw John Henry Menton casually in the Bodega just now and it will cost me a fall if I don’t...: 2.3354435735424617
Wait awhile...: 4.74485415493717
We’re on the right lay, Bob, believe you me.: 2.5573744440731647
—For a few days tell him, Father Cowley said anxiously.: 2.8714351391863677

—What few days?: 1.678668875053785
he boomed.: 2.4103103259201877
Hasn’t your landlord distrained for rent?: 3.3969541915531076

The landlord has the prior claim.: 1.4450916765848114
I gave him all the particulars.: 2.6296382796107656
29 Windsor avenue.: 1.4930137588154304
Love is the name?: 11.274654805180814
—That’s right, Father Cowley said.: 2.969409205151077
The reverend Mr Love.: 2.8847731027552252
He’s a minister in the country somewhere.: 3.2825186360668517
But are you sure of that?: 4.634704194980249
—You can tell Barabbas from me, Ben Dollard said, that he can put that writ where Jacko put the nuts.: 2.6044482428663938
—Filberts I believe they were, Mr Dedalus said, as he dropped his glasses on his coatfront, following them.: 4.003560978327204
*    *    *   —The youngster will be all right, Martin Cunningham said, as they passed out of the Castleyard gate.: 3.314455630740777
The policeman touched his forehead.: 2.7841682635031173
—God bless you, Martin Cunningham said, cheerily.: 2.364649567062656

Bronze by gold, Miss Kennedy’s head by Miss Douce’s head, appeared above the crossblind of the Ormond hotel.: 2.199789266191218
—Yes, Martin Cunningham said, fingering his beard.: 3.092982667392775
I wrote to Father Conmee and laid the whole case before him.: 2.4117850941309653
—You could try our friend, Mr Power suggested backward.: 3.4741165666693616

Martin Cunningham said shortly.: 5.812857446082679
Touch me not.: 1.5055783564392837

I see Bloom put his name down for five shillings.: 1.8069611746290115
—Quite right, Martin Cunningham said, taking the list.: 3.06418981333535
And put down the five shillings too.: 2.6288429898310017

John Wyse Nolan opened wide eyes.: 4.543885666569737
—I’ll say there is much kindness in the jew, he quoted, elegantly.: 2.9595069066388033

—There’s Jimmy Henry, Mr Power said, just heading for Kavanagh’s.: 2.8147952413753625
—Righto, Martin Cunningham said.: 2.0987340021609593
Here goes.: 1.3477879968310045
Outside _la Maison Claire_ Blazes Boylan waylaid Jack Mooney’s brother-in-law, humpy, tight, making for the liberties.: 1.9215512740702814
John Wyse Nolan fell back with Mr Power, while Martin Cunningham took the elbow of a dapper little man in a shower of hail suit, who walked uncertainly, with hasty steps past Micky Anderson’s watches.: 2.0141816525740057
—The assistant town clerk’s corns are giving him some trouble, John Wyse Nolan told Mr Power.: 1.7000418404811606
They followed round the corner towards James Kavanagh’s winerooms.: 1.8952750377357666
The empty castle car fronted them at rest in Essex gate.: 1.5324268435833837
Martin Cunningham, speaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not glance.: 1.6542714177514588
—And long John Fanning is here too, John Wyse Nolan said, as large as life.: 2.330906011075837
The tall form of long John Fanning filled the doorway where he stood.: 1.8677765484319084
Long John Fanning made no way for them.: 2.1162842003924602
He removed his large Henry Clay decisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all their faces.: 1.7670694372084619
—Are the conscript fathers pursuing their peaceful deliberations?: 1.8953586208777717
he said with rich acrid utterance to the assistant town clerk.: 1.78847820365431
Hell open to christians they were having, Jimmy Henry said pettishly, about their damned Irish language.: 1.7272858114695753
Where was the marshal, he wanted to know, to keep order in the council chamber.: 2.4845584346794105
And old Barlow the macebearer laid up with asthma, no mace on the table, nothing in order, no quorum even, and Hutchinson, the lord mayor, in Llandudno and little Lorcan Sherlock doing _locum tenens_ for him.: 2.873848391048797
Damned Irish language, language of our forefathers.: 1.8050542889530838
Long John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips.: 2.059152678046667
Martin Cunningham spoke by turns, twirling the peak of his beard, to the assistant town clerk and the subsheriff, while John Wyse Nolan held his peace.: 1.9766874662144003
—What Dignam was that?: 1.5910149887809224
long John Fanning asked.: 3.2886049684597327
Jimmy Henry made a grimace and lifted his left foot.: 2.151244425279818
—O, my corns!: 6.455957476671858
he said plaintively.: 1.2012846516222362
Come upstairs for goodness’ sake till I sit down somewhere.: 1.5398030252197088
Uff!: 8.936658005791672
Ooo!: 8.936658005791672
Mind!: 6.773273060191212
Testily he made room for himself beside long John Fanning’s flank and passed in and up the stairs.: 1.9427207272275668
—Come on up, Martin Cunningham said to the subsheriff.: 3.4472361672125618

With John Wyse Nolan Mr Power followed them in.: 3.075480191750663

—Rather lowsized.: 4.141571821272434
Dignam of Menton’s office that was, Martin Cunningham said.: 2.1994186539103517

Clatter of horsehoofs sounded from the air.: 1.8290154737984872
—What’s that?: 3.1816935079248982
All turned where they stood.: 1.5042057693728623
John Wyse Nolan came down again.: 2.4053664686061365

In saddles of the leaders, leaping leaders, rode outriders.: 1.8798780329810219
—What was it?: 9.971309348478227
Martin Cunningham asked, as they went on up the staircase.: 2.4882260702357235

*    *    *   As they trod across the thick carpet Buck Mulligan whispered behind his Panama to Haines:  —Parnell’s brother.: 1.8112858233537947
There in the corner.: 5.789226519854399
They chose a small table near the window, opposite a longfaced man whose beard and gaze hung intently down on a chessboard.: 2.2033419364363835
—Is that he?: 6.309624961247299
Haines asked, twisting round in his seat.: 2.666739340859076
—Yes, Mulligan said.: 4.509777179050977
That’s John Howard, his brother, our city marshal.: 2.3716612675946895
John Howard Parnell translated a white bishop quietly and his grey claw went up again to his forehead whereat it rested.: 1.7146401479793285
An instant after, under its screen, his eyes looked quickly, ghostbright, at his foe and fell once more upon a working corner.: 2.3427692513000435
—Two _mélanges,_ Buck Mulligan said.: 4.364115699319379
And bring us some scones and butter and some cakes as well.: 1.6710030578564337
When she had gone he said, laughing:  —We call it D.B.C.: 2.603104336561873
because they have damn bad cakes.: 1.4541874268397754
O, but you missed Dedalus on _Hamlet._  Haines opened his newbought book.: 1.7646086428166015
The onelegged sailor growled at the area of 14 Nelson street:  —_England expects_...: 1.8453585411746214
Buck Mulligan’s primrose waistcoat shook gaily to his laughter.: 2.3809799745147697
—You should see him, he said, when his body loses its balance.: 2.708928328667748
Wandering Ængus I call him.: 1.8292239038807334
—I am sure he has an _idée fixe,_ Haines said, pinching his chin thoughtfully with thumb and forefinger.: 3.001014395582996
Now I am speculating what it would be likely to be.: 2.657023749183788
Such persons always have.: 1.342287476137993
Buck Mulligan bent across the table gravely.: 2.8369363396374965
—They drove his wits astray, he said, by visions of hell.: 2.340935455744889
He will never capture the Attic note.: 1.7708519859951681
The note of Swinburne, of all poets, the white death and the ruddy birth.: 1.9120313274513214
That is his tragedy.: 2.027543417941256
He can never be a poet.: 2.4171967396813794
The joy of creation...: 6.689777035496708
—Eternal punishment, Haines said, nodding curtly.: 2.3179655867036972
I see.: 4.227860513001554
I tackled him this morning on belief.: 2.535804980308744
There was something on his mind, I saw.: 3.312610968731054
It’s rather interesting because professor Pokorny of Vienna makes an interesting point out of that.: 2.274671322998975
Buck Mulligan’s watchful eyes saw the waitress come.: 1.7653282029160144
He helped her to unload her tray.: 3.8657392982789327
—He can find no trace of hell in ancient Irish myth, Haines said, amid the cheerful cups.: 1.9030381729535988
The moral idea seems lacking, the sense of destiny, of retribution.: 1.6340274442267626
Rather strange he should have just that fixed idea.: 1.6483659388543725
Does he write anything for your movement?: 1.4441663452824955
He sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream.: 1.6667888567570006
Buck Mulligan slit a steaming scone in two and plastered butter over its smoking pith.: 1.3705526998073532
He bit off a soft piece hungrily.: 2.7970782224872104
—Ten years, he said, chewing and laughing.: 3.330053595437117
He is going to write something in ten years.: 2.9227499668373507
—Seems a long way off, Haines said, thoughtfully lifting his spoon.: 2.1494289926920835
Still, I shouldn’t wonder if he did after all.: 2.3707486319749105

—This is real Irish cream I take it, he said with forbearance.: 2.7309871105341355
I don’t want to be imposed on.: 3.19052903759184

Distantly behind him a blind stripling tapped his way by the wall of College park.: 2.06039240467637
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walked as far as Mr Lewis Werner’s cheerful windows, then turned and strode back along Merrion square, his stickumbrelladustcoat dangling.: 1.5861018136513316

With ratsteeth bared he muttered:  —_Coactus volui._  He strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word.: 1.8696756826768954

The blind stripling turned his sickly face after the striding form.: 2.1780908849426805
You’re blinder nor I am, you bitch’s bastard!: 3.2798741521819457
*    *    *   Opposite Ruggy O’Donohoe’s Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam, pawing the pound and a half of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s, porksteaks he had been sent for, went along warm Wicklow street dawdling.: 2.0222655534713168
It was too blooming dull sitting in the parlour with Mrs Stoer and Mrs Quigley and Mrs MacDowell and the blind down and they all at their sniffles and sipping sups of the superior tawny sherry uncle Barney brought from Tunney’s.: 1.971520001226616
And they eating crumbs of the cottage fruitcake, jawing the whole blooming time and sighing.: 2.290496340184315
After Wicklow lane the window of Madame Doyle, courtdress milliner, stopped him.: 2.365033937226024
He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their pelts and putting up their props.: 2.241604933086057
From the sidemirrors two mourning Masters Dignam gaped silently.: 2.375033285616645
Myler Keogh, Dublin’s pet lamb, will meet sergeantmajor Bennett, the Portobello bruiser, for a purse of fifty sovereigns.: 1.7028463123343422
Gob, that’d be a good pucking match to see.: 2.929195979948965
Myler Keogh, that’s the chap sparring out to him with the green sash.: 2.7630199510820277
Two bar entrance, soldiers half price.: 1.2449359421078783
Master Dignam on his left turned as he turned.: 1.7996011981955742
That’s me in mourning.: 4.289075760687918
When is it?: 2.63788803822321
May the twentysecond.: 1.7830918174835126
Sure, the blooming thing is all over.: 1.6175002798436624
He turned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry, his collar sticking up.: 2.3327398212382082
Buttoning it down, his chin lifted, he saw the image of Marie Kendall, charming soubrette, beside the two puckers.: 1.8313566207809218
One of them mots that do be in the packets of fags Stoer smokes that his old fellow welted hell out of him for one time he found out.: 2.2471619689504623
Master Dignam got his collar down and dawdled on.: 1.442967201491122
The best pucker going for strength was Fitzsimons.: 1.4631538241524267
One puck in the wind from that fellow would knock you into the middle of next week, man.: 1.9641979464950263
But the best pucker for science was Jem Corbet before Fitzsimons knocked the stuffings out of him, dodging and all.: 1.9515650099157549
In Grafton street Master Dignam saw a red flower in a toff’s mouth and a swell pair of kicks on him and he listening to what the drunk was telling him and grinning all the time.: 1.8720913682090556
No Sandymount tram.: 1.208982283489613
Master Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to his other hand.: 1.5451672906192
His collar sprang up again and he tugged it down.: 1.784236071741893
The blooming stud was too small for the buttonhole of the shirt, blooming end to it.: 1.5244254239578003
He met schoolboys with satchels.: 1.2301448476077335
I’m not going tomorrow either, stay away till Monday.: 2.156756229846097
He met other schoolboys.: 1.2444023084665035
Uncle Barney said he’d get it into the paper tonight.: 2.5715013917261857
Then they’ll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa’s name.: 2.322539661994435
His face got all grey instead of being red like it was and there was a fly walking over it up to his eye.: 2.145481980433429
The scrunch that was when they were screwing the screws into the coffin: and the bumps when they were bringing it downstairs.: 2.4560851715707606
Pa was inside it and ma crying in the parlour and uncle Barney telling the men how to get it round the bend.: 1.8030942996666728
A big coffin it was, and high and heavylooking.: 2.090207179230094
How was that?: 1.7893381111892495
The last night pa was boosed he was standing on the landing there bawling out for his boots to go out to Tunney’s for to boose more and he looked butty and short in his shirt.: 1.8219172613055803
Never see him again.: 2.036349145635212
Death, that is.: 5.178471908590899
My father is dead.: 1.5082017391380362
He told me to be a good son to ma.: 2.928874457518552
I couldn’t hear the other things he said but I saw his tongue and his teeth trying to say it better.: 2.3682714877529207
Poor pa.: 1.6118013555443254
That was Mr Dignam, my father.: 1.907661226961209
I hope he’s in purgatory now because he went to confession to Father Conroy on Saturday night.: 2.7286950027688497

_Done._     [ 12 ]   I was just passing the time of day with old Troy of the D.: 2.375607862033218
M.: 4.1967016971666
at the corner of Arbour hill there and be damned but a bloody sweep came along and he near drove his gear into my eye.: 1.8109538042954438
I turned around to let him have the weight of my tongue when who should I see dodging along Stony Batter only Joe Hynes.: 2.0636625687621577
—Lo, Joe, says I.: 2.0443158802231896
How are you blowing?: 3.2825808692532057
Did you see that bloody chimneysweep near shove my eye out with his brush?: 2.7313888317529815
—Soot’s luck, says Joe.: 2.9631752159854416
Who’s the old ballocks you were talking to?: 4.499332628972756
—Old Troy, says I, was in the force.: 3.6117666243755577
I’m on two minds not to give that fellow in charge for obstructing the thoroughfare with his brooms and ladders.: 3.1457287583809834
—What are you doing round those parts?: 3.6314350435179756
—Devil a much, says I.: 1.912189228218133
There’s a bloody big foxy thief beyond by the garrison church at the corner of Chicken lane—old Troy was just giving me a wrinkle about him—lifted any God’s quantity of tea and sugar to pay three bob a week said he had a farm in the county Down off a hop-of-my-thumb by the name of Moses Herzog over there near Heytesbury street.: 1.9947789182482605
—Circumcised?: 6.8657470006643475
—Ay, says I.: 3.2299512748580868
A bit off the top.: 2.282892919275597
An old plumber named Geraghty.: 1.2311746135249364
I’m hanging on to his taw now for the past fortnight and I can’t get a penny out of him.: 2.707076295786426
—That the lay you’re on now?: 5.166402161285667
—Ay, says I.: 3.2299512748580868
How are the mighty fallen!: 1.8716288071969063
Collector of bad and doubtful debts.: 1.4048947971217238

Because he no pay me my moneys?_  For nonperishable goods bought of Moses Herzog, of 13 Saint Kevin’s parade in the city of Dublin, Wood quay ward, merchant, hereinafter called the vendor, and sold and delivered to Michael E.: 1.7829789712893223
Geraghty, esquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward, gentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds avoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per pound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal, at threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the said vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value received which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in weekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no pence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall be and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the said vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the said amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said vendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between the said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one part and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the other part.: 1.7154801595623093

In Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan.: 2.222954053707913
There rises a watchtower beheld of men afar.: 1.5795504693150348
There sleep the mighty dead as in life they slept, warriors and princes of high renown.: 1.854227981957779
A pleasant land it is in sooth of murmuring waters, fishful streams where sport the gurnard, the plaice, the roach, the halibut, the gibbed haddock, the grilse, the dab, the brill, the flounder, the pollock, the mixed coarse fish generally and other denizens of the aqueous kingdom too numerous to be enumerated.: 2.5636379385922394
In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty trees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty sycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic eucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which that region is thoroughly well supplied.: 2.5498553607944556
Lovely maidens sit in close proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings, creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects.: 1.9279070150273683
And heroes voyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless princes of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth sleek Leinster and of Cruachan’s land and of Armagh the splendid and of the noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings.: 1.9753070968325308
And there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen by mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for that purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits of that land for O’Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain descended from chieftains.: 1.8826255570646675
Thither the extremely large wains bring foison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach, pineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs, drills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale, York and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of mushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red green yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and chips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious, and strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes.: 2.55154698260721
Come out here, Geraghty, you notorious bloody hill and dale robber!: 1.5062889167116935
And by that way wend the herds innumerable of bellwethers and flushed ewes and shearling rams and lambs and stubble geese and medium steers and roaring mares and polled calves and longwools and storesheep and Cuffe’s prime springers and culls and sowpigs and baconhogs and the various different varieties of highly distinguished swine and Angus heifers and polly bulllocks of immaculate pedigree together with prime premiated milchcows and beeves: and there is ever heard a trampling, cackling, roaring, lowing, bleating, bellowing, rumbling, grunting, champing, chewing, of sheep and pigs and heavyhooved kine from pasturelands of Lusk and Rush and Carrickmines and from the streamy vales of Thomond, from the M’Gillicuddy’s reeks the inaccessible and lordly Shannon the unfathomable, and from the gentle declivities of the place of the race of Kiar, their udders distended with superabundance of milk and butts of butter and rennets of cheese and farmer’s firkins and targets of lamb and crannocks of corn and oblong eggs in great hundreds, various in size, the agate with this dun.: 2.6489522142698063

A powerful current of warm breath issued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth while in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his formidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of the lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and tremble.: 1.7140017605918705
He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching to the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by a girdle of plaited straw and rushes.: 1.569169025668984

Questioned by his earthname as to his whereabouts in the heavenworld he stated that he was now on the path of prālāyā or return but was still submitted to trial at the hands of certain bloodthirsty entities on the lower astral levels.: 2.7303309509051545
In reply to a question as to his first sensations in the great divide beyond he stated that previously he had seen as in a glass darkly but that those who had passed over had summit possibilities of atmic development opened up to them.: 1.8329657217803246
Interrogated as to whether life there resembled our experience in the flesh he stated that he had heard from more favoured beings now in the spirit that their abodes were equipped with every modern home comfort such as tālāfānā, ālāvātār, hātākāldā, wātāklāsāt and that the highest adepts were steeped in waves of volupcy of the very purest nature.: 2.1324748730232335
Having requested a quart of buttermilk this was brought and evidently afforded relief.: 1.4390674800064291

The distinguished scientist Herr Professor Luitpold Blumenduft tendered medical evidence to the effect that the instantaneous fracture of the cervical vertebrae and consequent scission of the spinal cord would, according to the best approved tradition of medical science, be calculated to inevitably produce in the human subject a violent ganglionic stimulus of the nerve centres of the genital apparatus, thereby causing the elastic pores of the _corpora cavernosa_ to rapidly dilate in such a way as to instantaneously facilitate the flow of blood to that part of the human anatomy known as the penis or male organ resulting in the phenomenon which has been denominated by the faculty a morbid upwards and outwards philoprogenitive erection _in articulo mortis per diminutionem capitis._  So of course the citizen was only waiting for the wink of the word and he starts gassing out of him about the invincibles and the old guard and the men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight and Joe with him about all the fellows that were hanged, drawn and transported for the cause by drumhead courtmartial and a new Ireland and new this, that and the other.: 2.197703981674306

From the belfries far and near the funereal deathbell tolled unceasingly while all around the gloomy precincts rolled the ominous warning of a hundred muffled drums punctuated by the hollow booming of pieces of ordnance.: 1.6862970959460895
The deafening claps of thunder and the dazzling flashes of lightning which lit up the ghastly scene testified that the artillery of heaven had lent its supernatural pomp to the already gruesome spectacle.: 1.5044194833236932
A torrential rain poured down from the floodgates of the angry heavens upon the bared heads of the assembled multitude which numbered at the lowest computation five hundred thousand persons.: 1.9918757627030603
A posse of Dublin Metropolitan police superintended by the Chief Commissioner in person maintained order in the vast throng for whom the York street brass and reed band whiled away the intervening time by admirably rendering on their blackdraped instruments the matchless melody endeared to us from the cradle by Speranza’s plaintive muse.: 1.9217624781904017

The arrival of the worldrenowned headsman was greeted by a roar of acclamation from the huge concourse, the viceregal ladies waving their handkerchiefs in their excitement while the even more excitable foreign delegates cheered vociferously in a medley of cries, _hoch, banzai, eljen, zivio, chinchin, polla kronia, hiphip, vive, Allah_, amid which the ringing _evviva_ of the delegate of the land of song (a high double F recalling those piercingly lovely notes with which the eunuch Catalani beglamoured our greatgreatgrandmothers) was easily distinguishable.: 2.0744822049737497

The learned prelate who administered the last comforts of holy religion to the hero martyr when about to pay the death penalty knelt in a most christian spirit in a pool of rainwater, his cassock above his hoary head, and offered up to the throne of grace fervent prayers of supplication.: 1.5637231631454553
Hard by the block stood the grim figure of the executioner, his visage being concealed in a tengallon pot with two circular perforated apertures through which his eyes glowered furiously.: 2.2676826085682307
As he awaited the fatal signal he tested the edge of his horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or decapitated in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been provided by the admirers of his fell but necessary office.: 1.748695785143421
On a handsome mahogany table near him were neatly arranged the quartering knife, the various finely tempered disembowelling appliances (specially supplied by the worldfamous firm of cutlers, Messrs John Round and Sons, Sheffield), a terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the duodenum, colon, blind intestine and appendix etc when successfully extracted and two commodious milkjugs destined to receive the most precious blood of the most precious victim.: 2.3217344568257974
The housesteward of the amalgamated cats’ and dogs’ home was in attendance to convey these vessels when replenished to that beneficent institution.: 2.289445269712375
Quite an excellent repast consisting of rashers and eggs, fried steak and onions, done to a nicety, delicious hot breakfast rolls and invigorating tea had been considerately provided by the authorities for the consumption of the central figure of the tragedy who was in capital spirits when prepared for death and evinced the keenest interest in the proceedings from beginning to end but he, with an abnegation rare in these our times, rose nobly to the occasion and expressed the dying wish (immediately acceded to) that the meal should be divided in aliquot parts among the members of the sick and indigent roomkeepers’ association as a token of his regard and esteem.: 1.7605888086650487
The _nec_ and _non plus ultra_ of emotion were reached when the blushing bride elect burst her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders and flung herself upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be launched into eternity for her sake.: 1.6833694907977814
The hero folded her willowy form in a loving embrace murmuring fondly _Sheila, my own_.: 2.37453813501919
Encouraged by this use of her christian name she kissed passionately all the various suitable areas of his person which the decencies of prison garb permitted her ardour to reach.: 1.8616872670692457
She swore to him as they mingled the salt streams of their tears that she would ever cherish his memory, that she would never forget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his lips as if he were but going to a hurling match in Clonturk park.: 1.9069626566767506
She brought back to his recollection the happy days of blissful childhood together on the banks of Anna Liffey when they had indulged in the innocent pastimes of the young and, oblivious of the dreadful present, they both laughed heartily, all the spectators, including the venerable pastor, joining in the general merriment.: 1.684967763808921
That monster audience simply rocked with delight.: 1.2711997973548779

Big strong men, officers of the peace and genial giants of the royal Irish constabulary, were making frank use of their handkerchiefs and it is safe to say that there was not a dry eye in that record assemblage.: 1.9123339521417178
A most romantic incident occurred when a handsome young Oxford graduate, noted for his chivalry towards the fair sex, stepped forward and, presenting his visiting card, bankbook and genealogical tree, solicited the hand of the hapless young lady, requesting her to name the day, and was accepted on the spot.: 1.9991310131484525
Every lady in the audience was presented with a tasteful souvenir of the occasion in the shape of a skull and crossbones brooch, a timely and generous act which evoked a fresh outburst of emotion: and when the gallant young Oxonian (the bearer, by the way, of one of the most timehonoured names in Albion’s history) placed on the finger of his blushing _fiancée_ an expensive engagement ring with emeralds set in the form of a fourleaved shamrock the excitement knew no bounds.: 1.9662741837424371

All those who are interested in the spread of human culture among the lower animals (and their name is legion) should make a point of not missing the really marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy given by the famous old Irish red setter wolfdog formerly known by the _sobriquet_ of Garryowen and recently rechristened by his large circle of friends and acquaintances Owen Garry.: 1.6280478606968813
The exhibition, which is the result of years of training by kindness and a carefully thoughtout dietary system, comprises, among other achievements, the recitation of verse.: 2.1209599671307773
Our greatest living phonetic expert (wild horses shall not drag it from us!) has left no stone unturned in his efforts to delucidate and compare the verse recited and has found it bears a _striking_ resemblance (the italics are ours) to the ranns of ancient Celtic bards.: 1.7414332712024927
We are not speaking so much of those delightful lovesongs with which the writer who conceals his identity under the graceful pseudonym of the Little Sweet Branch has familiarised the bookloving world but rather (as a contributor D.: 1.7406423297753322
C.: 2.4776009465393525
points out in an interesting communication published by an evening contemporary) of the harsher and more personal note which is found in the satirical effusions of the famous Raftery and of Donal MacConsidine to say nothing of a more modern lyrist at present very much in the public eye.: 2.48144897808958
We subjoin a specimen which has been rendered into English by an eminent scholar whose name for the moment we are not at liberty to disclose though we believe that our readers will find the topical allusion rather more than an indication.: 1.601498482415838
The metrical system of the canine original, which recalls the intricate alliterative and isosyllabic rules of the Welsh englyn, is infinitely more complicated but we believe our readers will agree that the spirit has been well caught.: 1.9146650377625558

A most interesting discussion took place in the ancient hall of _Brian O’Ciarnain’s_ in _Sraid na Bretaine Bheag_, under the auspices of _Sluagh na h-Eireann_, on the revival of ancient Gaelic sports and the importance of physical culture, as understood in ancient Greece and ancient Rome and ancient Ireland, for the development of the race.: 2.1310049199066037
The venerable president of the noble order was in the chair and the attendance was of large dimensions.: 1.8390889430033472
After an instructive discourse by the chairman, a magnificent oration eloquently and forcibly expressed, a most interesting and instructive discussion of the usual high standard of excellence ensued as to the desirability of the revivability of the ancient games and sports of our ancient Panceltic forefathers.: 2.0329773801313276
The wellknown and highly respected worker in the cause of our old tongue, Mr Joseph M’Carthy Hynes, made an eloquent appeal for the resuscitation of the ancient Gaelic sports and pastimes, practised morning and evening by Finn MacCool, as calculated to revive the best traditions of manly strength and prowess handed down to us from ancient ages.: 1.8754256135014606
L.: 1.8800475069023828
Bloom, who met with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the negative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in response to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of a bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal Thomas Osborne Davis’ evergreen verses (happily too familiar to need recalling here) _A nation once again_ in the execution of which the veteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction to have fairly excelled himself.: 1.8851462637979226
The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in superlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest advantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing it.: 1.6268496861221307

The maids of honour, Miss Larch Conifer and Miss Spruce Conifer, sisters of the bride, wore very becoming costumes in the same tone, a dainty _motif_ of plume rose being worked into the pleats in a pinstripe and repeated capriciously in the jadegreen toques in the form of heron feathers of paletinted coral.: 2.5202626170514404

says John Wyse.: 3.7306511025984066

says Bloom.: 2.0454007671254297
A nation is the same people living in the same place.: 2.6690693054129437
—By God, then, says Ned, laughing, if that’s so I’m a nation for I’m living in the same place for the past five years.: 3.3495498474223386
So of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck out of it:  —Or also living in different places.: 2.6402227762459143

Ireland.: 4.191627417336141

—After you with the push, Joe, says he, taking out his handkerchief to swab himself dry.: 2.8538202553895835
—Here you are, citizen, says Joe.: 2.290035012572513
Take that in your right hand and repeat after me the following words.: 1.8515741035177962
The muchtreasured and intricately embroidered ancient Irish facecloth attributed to Solomon of Droma and Manus Tomaltach og MacDonogh, authors of the Book of Ballymote, was then carefully produced and called forth prolonged admiration.: 2.774516879918396
No need to dwell on the legendary beauty of the cornerpieces, the acme of art, wherein one can distinctly discern each of the four evangelists in turn presenting to each of the four masters his evangelical symbol, a bogoak sceptre, a North American puma (a far nobler king of beasts than the British article, be it said in passing), a Kerry calf and a golden eagle from Carrantuohill.: 1.8919426866077766
The scenes depicted on the emunctory field, showing our ancient duns and raths and cromlechs and grianauns and seats of learning and maledictive stones, are as wonderfully beautiful and the pigments as delicate as when the Sligo illuminators gave free rein to their artistic fantasy long long ago in the time of the Barmecides.: 2.3522582112065735
Glendalough, the lovely lakes of Killarney, the ruins of Clonmacnois, Cong Abbey, Glen Inagh and the Twelve Pins, Ireland’s Eye, the Green Hills of Tallaght, Croagh Patrick, the brewery of Messrs Arthur Guinness, Son and Company (Limited), Lough Neagh’s banks, the vale of Ovoca, Isolde’s tower, the Mapas obelisk, Sir Patrick Dun’s hospital, Cape Clear, the glen of Aherlow, Lynch’s castle, the Scotch house, Rathdown Union Workhouse at Loughlinstown, Tullamore jail, Castleconnel rapids, Kilballymacshonakill, the cross at Monasterboice, Jury’s Hotel, S.: 2.346950767254927
Patrick’s Purgatory, the Salmon Leap, Maynooth college refectory, Curley’s hole, the three birthplaces of the first duke of Wellington, the rock of Cashel, the bog of Allen, the Henry Street Warehouse, Fingal’s Cave—all these moving scenes are still there for us today rendered more beautiful still by the waters of sorrow which have passed over them and by the rich incrustations of time.: 2.1496081771100135

So the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts reading out:  —A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented yesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting, Lord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt thanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his dominions.: 1.7492356773427191
The delegation partook of luncheon at the conclusion of which the dusky potentate, in the course of a happy speech, freely translated by the British chaplain, the reverend Ananias Praisegod Barebones, tendered his best thanks to Massa Walkup and emphasised the cordial relations existing between Abeakuta and the British empire, stating that he treasured as one of his dearest possessions an illuminated bible, the volume of the word of God and the secret of England’s greatness, graciously presented to him by the white chief woman, the great squaw Victoria, with a personal dedication from the august hand of the Royal Donor.: 2.154099068351381
The Alaki then drank a lovingcup of firstshot usquebaugh to the toast _Black and White_ from the skull of his immediate predecessor in the dynasty Kakachakachak, surnamed Forty Warts, after which he visited the chief factory of Cottonopolis and signed his mark in the visitors’ book, subsequently executing a charming old Abeakutic wardance, in the course of which he swallowed several knives and forks, amid hilarious applause from the girl hands.: 2.208745368208492

And as they wended their way by Nelson’s Pillar, Henry street, Mary street, Capel street, Little Britain street chanting the introit in _Epiphania Domini_ which beginneth _Surge, illuminare_ and thereafter most sweetly the gradual _Omnes_ which saith _de Saba venient_ they did divers wonders such as casting out devils, raising the dead to life, multiplying fishes, healing the halt and the blind, discovering various articles which had been mislaid, interpreting and fulfilling the scriptures, blessing and prophesying.: 1.8831915431134276
And last, beneath a canopy of cloth of gold came the reverend Father O’Flynn attended by Malachi and Patrick.: 1.9763985597516962

The catastrophe was terrific and instantaneous in its effect.: 1.3545022750636777
The observatory of Dunsink registered in all eleven shocks, all of the fifth grade of Mercalli’s scale, and there is no record extant of a similar seismic disturbance in our island since the earthquake of 1534, the year of the rebellion of Silken Thomas.: 2.0917466495271624
The epicentre appears to have been that part of the metropolis which constitutes the Inn’s Quay ward and parish of Saint Michan covering a surface of fortyone acres, two roods and one square pole or perch.: 1.6895226509663106
All the lordly residences in the vicinity of the palace of justice were demolished and that noble edifice itself, in which at the time of the catastrophe important legal debates were in progress, is literally a mass of ruins beneath which it is to be feared all the occupants have been buried alive.: 1.7487616582569308
From the reports of eyewitnesses it transpires that the seismic waves were accompanied by a violent atmospheric perturbation of cyclonic character.: 1.958622936234964
An article of headgear since ascertained to belong to the much respected clerk of the crown and peace Mr George Fottrell and a silk umbrella with gold handle with the engraved initials, crest, coat of arms and house number of the erudite and worshipful chairman of quarter sessions sir Frederick Falkiner, recorder of Dublin, have been discovered by search parties in remote parts of the island respectively, the former on the third basaltic ridge of the giant’s causeway, the latter embedded to the extent of one foot three inches in the sandy beach of Holeopen bay near the old head of Kinsale.: 1.7133171595689929
Messages of condolence and sympathy are being hourly received from all parts of the different continents and the sovereign pontiff has been graciously pleased to decree that a special _missa pro defunctis_ shall be celebrated simultaneously by the ordinaries of each and every cathedral church of all the episcopal dioceses subject to the spiritual authority of the Holy See in suffrage of the souls of those faithful departed who have been so unexpectedly called away from our midst.: 2.1464916920899526

[ 13 ]   The summer evening had begun to fold the world in its mysterious embrace.: 1.5755753613355221
Far away in the west the sun was setting and the last glow of all too fleeting day lingered lovingly on sea and strand, on the proud promontory of dear old Howth guarding as ever the waters of the bay, on the weedgrown rocks along Sandymount shore and, last but not least, on the quiet church whence there streamed forth at times upon the stillness the voice of prayer to her who is in her pure radiance a beacon ever to the stormtossed heart of man, Mary, star of the sea.: 2.098828755341089
The three girl friends were seated on the rocks, enjoying the evening scene and the air which was fresh but not too chilly.: 1.7057472778827232
